channel.title: All blog posts featured by QuantStack team
channel.description: RSS feed for QuantStack website blog page

item.title: Create your own layers in JupyterGIS
item.description: JupyterGIS-tiler is a JupyterGIS extension that lets you use a notebook to process your (Xarray) data and make it available as raster tiles, so that it can be visualized in JupyterGIS.
item.dc:creator: David Brochart

item.title: C++ in Jupyter â€” Interpreting C++ in the Web
item.description: Scientists and engineers utilize programming languages not only to build software systems but also to drive interactive exploratory workflows. They leverage developer tools to explore and reason through problems effectively.
item.dc:creator: Anutosh Bhat, Vassil Vassilev

item.title: JupyterLite 0.6.0 is released! ðŸŽ‰
item.description: The new 0.6.0 release includes a number of new features, bug fixes, and enhancements. This release also brings significant improvements to the user experience and new customization options for JupyterLite deployments.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Tuloup

item.title: JupyterLab 4.4 and Notebook 7.4 are available!
item.description: JupyterLab 4.4 has been released! This new minor release of JupyterLab includes 28 new features and enhancements, 76 bug fixes, 63 maintenance tasks and 34 documentation improvements.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Tuloup

item.title: Congratulations, Distinguished Contributors!
item.description: We are proud to announce the recipients of the Jupyter Distinguished Contributor (JDC) award for the 2024 cohort of contributors.
item.dc:creator: Johan Mabille

item.title: Making Qt collaborative using CRDTs
item.description: A journal on creating a collaborative application with Qt
item.dc:creator: David Brochart

item.title: R in the Browser: Announcing Our WebAssembly Distribution
item.description: R is now available in emscripten-forge, enabling the Xeus-R kernel in JupyterLite.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Paredes

item.title: Real-time collaboration and collaborative editing for GIS workflows with Jupyter and QGIS
item.description: We are excited to announce JupyterGIS, a web-based, collaborative, and extensible interface for GIS, leveraging the JupyterLab application framework and integrating seamlessly with the Jupyter notebook interface.
item.dc:creator: Meriem Ben Ismail, Nicolas Brichet, David Brochart, Matt Fisher, Anne Fouilloux, Greg Mooney, Martin Renou, Arjun Verma

item.title: PyData Paris 2025 Keynotes
item.description: We are thrilled to announce the keynote speakers for the upcoming PyData Paris 2025, the leading gathering of the open-source data science and AI/ML community in France.
item.dc:creator: Sandrine Pataut

item.title: Announcing JupyterCAD 3.0
item.description: We are thrilled to introduce JupyterCAD 3.0, the newest version of the collaborative CAD modeler designed for JupyterLab.
item.dc:creator: Arjun Verma, Trung Le, Martin Renou

item.title: Sparrow
item.description: We are thrilled to introduce Sparrow, a new library designed to simplify the integration of Apache Arrowâ€™s columnar format into C++ applications.
item.dc:creator: Johan Mabille, Alexis Placet, Thorsten Beier, JoÃ«l Lamotte

item.title: JupyterLite Terminal
item.description: QuantStack are delighted to announce that we have been working on a new Terminal for JupyterLite.
item.dc:creator: Ian Thomas

item.title: Automate your releases with the Jupyter Releaser ðŸš€
item.description: Jupyter Releaser is an automation tool developed by the Jupyter team to streamline and standardize the release process across Jupyter projects.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Tuloup

item.title: QuantStack Steps Up to Support Apache Arrow with New Dedicated Team
item.description: We are thrilled to announce that QuantStack is starting a new team dedicated to the maintenance and development of Apache Arrow.
item.dc:creator: Sylvain Corlay

item.title: Interactive Mapping with ipyopenlayers
item.description: In this article, we present the main features of ipyopenlayers and demonstrate how this library can transform your geospatial data into dynamic, interactive visualizations.
item.dc:creator: Nour Cheour

item.title: Announcing the 2023 cohort of Jupyter distinguished contributors
item.description: We are delighted to announce the recipients of the Jupyter Distinguished Contributor (JDC) award for the 2023 cohort.
item.dc:creator: Johan Mabille, on behalf of the Jupyter Distinguished Contributors

item.title: Ipydatagrid is now part of Project Jupyter
item.description: Today, we are proud to announce that the ipydatagrid open source project has been incorporated into Project Jupyter as part of the Jupyter Widgets subproject.
item.dc:creator: Sylvain Corlay, on behalf of the Jupyter Widgets Council

item.title: Introducing Mamba 2.0
item.description: We are excited to present the first release candidate of Mamba 2.0, a significant upgrade to the mamba package manager. This update brings considerable enhancements for both users and developers, following an extensive year-long development effort.
item.dc:creator: Antoine Prouvost, JoÃ«l Lamotte, Johan Mabille, Hind Montassif

item.title: QuantStack open-source internship program
item.description: Today, we are announcing a new internship program that aims to empower a new cohort of open-source contributors and future maintainers to make an impact within our ecosystem.
item.dc:creator: Sylvain Corlay

item.title: JupyterCAD 2.0
item.description: We are thrilled to introduce JupyterCAD 2.0, the newest version of the JupyterLab-based CAD modeler.
item.dc:creator: Trung Le, Martin Renou

item.title: JupyterGIS
item.description: We are thrilled to announce that the European Space Agency (ESA) is funding our proposal â€œReal-time collaboration and collaborative editing for GIS workflows with Jupyter and QGIS.â€
item.dc:creator: Sylvain Corlay, Anne Fouilloux, Monika Weissschnur

item.title: Commit!
item.description: Open-source projects are not just about the latest exciting updates and features, but also the principles and people that drive these projects to success. In this blog post, I reflect on the dynamicsâ€¦
item.dc:creator: Sylvain Corlay

item.title: In memoriam: Fanny Loustau Chartez
item.description: It is with great sadness that we announce the passing of our colleague and friend, Fanny Loustau Chartez, who served as the Chief Financial Officer of QuantStack since 2021.
item.dc:creator: Sylvain Corlay

item.title: Announcing PyData Paris 2024
item.description: We are thrilled to announce the upcoming PyData Paris 2024, the gathering of the open-source data science and AI/ML community in France. PyData Paris will take place at the CitÃ© des Sciences from September 25 to September 26, 2024.
item.dc:creator: Sylvain Corlay

item.title: Meet Xeus-R: a future-proof Jupyter kernel for R
item.description: Today, we, a collaborative team led by Romain FranÃ§ois and supported by QuantStack, are thrilled to announce the initial release of Xeus-R, a future-proof Jupyter kernel for R.
item.dc:creator: Romain FranÃ§ois

item.title: QuantStack: 2023 in review
item.description: Since QuantStack was founded in 2016, we have remained committed to releasing our work under permissive open-source licenses. Here are some highlights of the 2023 achievements. Buckle up!
item.dc:creator: Sylvain Corlay

item.title: Recent keyboard navigation improvements in Jupyter
item.description: Upcoming versions of JupyterLab (4.1.0) and Notebook (7.1.0) will include major keyboard accessibility fixes.
item.dc:creator: Nicolas Brichet, Gabriel Fouasnon

item.title: And Voici!
item.description: Voici (meaning â€œhere isâ€ in French) is a novel project reshaping Jupyter-based interactive dashboards by combining VoilÃ and JupyterLite features. It facilitates the creation of dynamic, in-browser environments for data visualization and exploration.
item.dc:creator: Trung Duc Le, Martin Renou

item.title: Plug your application into the Jupyter world
item.description: Kernels are a simple but powerful abstraction in the Jupyter architecture. They encapsulate language interpreters and make them accessible through a standardized interface. This is the key toâ€¦
item.dc:creator: David Brochart

item.title: VoilÃ 0.5 - Homecoming
item.description: Following the launch of Jupyter Notebook 7, it is now VoilÃ â€™s turn to join the JupyterLab family. In Version 0.5.0, the front-end of VoilÃ has been rebuilt from scratch using JupyterLab 4.0 components, just like in the case of Notebook 7.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Tuloup, Martin Renou, Trung Duc Le

item.title: Announcing Jupyter Notebook 7
item.description: Jupyter Notebook 7 is the most significant release of the Jupyter Notebook in years. Some highlights of this release include real-time collaboration, interactive debugging, table of contents, theming and dark mode, internationalization, improved accessibility, compact view on mobile devices.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Tuloup

item.title: ðŸŽ‰ JupyterCon 2023 recordings now live on YouTube! ðŸŽ‰
item.description: Get ready to relive the magic of JupyterCon 2023, because the long-awaited moment is finally here! The JupyterCon YouTube channel has just dropped a treasure trove of content â€” all the talk and keynote recordings from the most epic conference of the year.
item.dc:creator: Gayle Ollington, Sylvain Corlay

item.title: A theme editor for JupyterLab
item.description: To lower the bar for customizing JupyterLab we created a new tool providing a simple interface for tuning the JupyterLab appearance interactively.
item.dc:creator: Florence Haudin

item.title: Collaborative CAD in JupyterLab
item.description: Introducing JupyterCAD, a tool that integrates Computer-Aided Design (CAD) capabilities into JupyterLab.
item.dc:creator: Duc Trung Le, Martin Renou

item.title: Congratulations, Distinguished Contributors!
item.description: We are proud to announce the recipients of the Jupyter Distinguished Contributor (JDC) award for the 2022 cohort of contributors.
item.dc:creator: Johan Mabille

item.title: Embed interactive itkwidgets 3D renderings into JupyterLite deployments
item.description: A tutorial that demonstrates a zero-server, interactive 3D rendering notebook and walks through the quick and easy configuration that can be customized to your needs.
item.dc:creator: Matt McCormick, Brianna Major, Jeremy Tuloup, Wei Ouyang, Stephen Aylward

item.title: Improving the accessibility of Jupyter
item.description: This article presents some of the recent accessibility improvements in the Jupyter Notebook codebase.
item.dc:creator: Nicolas Brichet, Johan Mabille, Jeremy Tuloup, FrÃ©dÃ©ric Collonval, Sylvain Corlay

item.title: A Jupyter kernel for GNU Octave
item.description: We are happy to announce the xeus-octave project, a Jupyter kernel for GNU Octave. Xeus-octave was created by Giulio Girardi, recently joined by Antoine Prouvost - and has been incorporated into the Project Jupyter governance.
item.dc:creator: Giulio Girardi, Antoine Prouvost

item.title: QuantStack: 2022 in review
item.description: 2022 was an amazing year of innovation for the open-source developers at QuantStack. Developments range from major improvements to the Jupyter project to the packaging ecosystem and high-performance computing.
item.dc:creator: Sylvain Corlay

item.title: Managing conflicts with Mamba
item.description: A key aspect of package management is finding a set of compatible versions of the required packages. Indeed, even in the case when few packages are explicitly required, second-order dependencies mayâ€¦
item.dc:creator: Antoine Prouvost

item.title: JupyterCon is back in 2023
item.description: JupyterCon 2023 will be held May 10â€“12 (Thursday to Friday) in the city of light, Paris, France at the largest science museum in Europe, the CitÃ© des Sciences et de lâ€™Industrie.
item.dc:creator: Gayle Ollington

item.title: Accelerating JupyterLab
item.description: The next major release of JupyterLab will be significantly faster than previous versions. This was achieved both through systematic tracking of performance bugs and through significant upgrades to the Jupyter communication protocol and rendering mechanism for documents.
item.dc:creator: FrÃ©dÃ©ric Collonval, Johan Mabille, David Brochart, Afshin Darian

item.title: Upgrading nbgrader
item.description: Project Jupyter provides a broad collection of open-source tools for interactive computing that has become ubiquitous in data science and scientific computing, and is very popular in educationalâ€¦
item.dc:creator: Nicolas Brichet

item.title: Visual programming in JupyterLab with Blockly
item.description: When moving from block-based programming to a more classical language like Python, students often have to switch to a completely new environment. In order to provide a smooth ramp of complexity for learners, we designed a JupyterLab extension for Blockly so that Jupyter can be used from the very first steps of their learning journey.
item.dc:creator: Denisa Checiu, Carlos Herrero

item.title: Mamba meets JupyterLite
item.description: JupyterLite is a Jupyter distribution that runs entirely in the web browser without any server components. To achieve this, all language kernels must also run in the browser. A significant benefit ofâ€¦
item.dc:creator: Thorsten Beier, Martin Renou

item.title: Inspector JupyterLab
item.description: JupyterLab provides multiple ways to improve your coding workflow: code highlighting, code completion, theming, debugger with rich variable rendering and more.
item.dc:creator: Martin Renou

item.title: HTML5 <canvas> based renderer for Matplotlib in Pyodide
item.description: In this post, we present a new backend for Matplotlib enabling the rendering of figures in the browser by leveraging the <canvas> element. This showcases how JavaScript and Python can interact with each other, thanks to Pyodide.
item.dc:creator: Madhur Tandon

item.title: The future of mamba
item.description: The recent adoption of libmamba by the conda project was a great validation of our work. Several other game-changing innovations are in the works by the mamba team. Stay tuned!
item.dc:creator: Wolf Vollprecht

item.title: Congratulations, Distinguished Contributors!
item.description: We are proud to announce the recipients of the Jupyter Distinguished Contributor (JDC) award for the 2021 cohort of contributors.
item.dc:creator: Johan Mabille

item.title: Jupyter Everywhere
item.description: Easily embed a console, a notebook, or a fully-fledged IDE on any web page.
item.dc:creator: Martin Renou, Jeremy Tuloup

item.title: ROS2 support for Zethus
item.description: Zethus is an Open Source library for Robot visualization in the browser. Initially developed by Rapyuta Robotics, it provides a web-basedâ€¦
item.dc:creator: Kedus Mathewos

item.title: QuantStack: 2021 in review
item.description: This was a crazy year of innovation for the open-source team at QuantStack. From JupyterLab to the packaging ecosystem and high-performance computing, we made some major strides in all areas, while almost doubling the size of the team.
item.dc:creator: Sylvain Corlay

item.title: Jupyter Games
item.description: Making their own tiny video games can be a great way for kids to learn programming in a playful matter. While Jupyter is widely used as a scientific and educational tool, Jupyter is seldom used as aâ€¦

item.title: Need for speed: VoilÃ edition
item.description: VoilÃ turns Jupyter notebooks into standalone applications without requiring any modification to the content. You want to share your content with non-technical readers? Just call VoilÃ with theâ€¦

item.description: Supply chain security is crucial to the overall security of package managers, which are a major attack vector of information systems. Today, we are pleased to announce that mamba has gained theâ€¦

item.title: Toward a faster and thinner xsimd
item.description: xsimd, the SIMD library by QuantStack, got more and more adoption in recent years. While it helped improve the library, adoption also brought new requirements. Among them was the abitility to...

item.title: Xeus-Lite
item.description: JupyterLite is a JupyterLab distribution that runs entirely in the web browser, backed by in-browser language kernels. Xeus is C++ library for writing Jupyter kernels. In this blogpost we show howâ€¦

item.title: The mamba project and the CZI grant

item.title: Looking at notebooks from a new perspective
item.description: Jupyter notebooks are a great tool for practitioners of scientific computing from the research phase of their work to the communication of their results. The interleaving of code and rich text makesâ€¦

item.title: Xeus 2.0
item.description: We have just released Xeus 2.0. This is a major release of the library. While it includes backward-incompatible changes, they are very limited and upgrading your kernels should be relatively easyâ€¦

item.title: Mamba 0.15.0

item.title: RetroLab - A JupyterLab distribution with a retro look and feel
item.description: RetroLab is an alternative JupyterLab distribution, built from the ground-up, providing a notebook interface with a retro look and feel. Currently at version 3.0, JupyterLab provides an advancedâ€¦

item.title: Rhumba, the fast R distribution is available on Windows
